text: Dégustée à température de 7 à 10°C. Corps ambre rosé intense, opaque; mousse ivoire très peu dense, savonneuse, qui fond complètement. Arômes de cerise aigre fine, fruits confits; quelque chose de floral. On retrouve tout cela en bouche avec également une acidité fruitée et boisée. Robuste sans être rustique. Bel équilibre, grande finesse. Saccorde merveilleusement bien avec un pain à la faine de châtaigne aux noisettes et aux figues.

Bottle shared at KLs 10K rating celebration. Tart fruit nose, light bit of lactic note, some caramel. Deep orange/amber color. Tart sour fruit, peach, mild cherry, citrus squeezes, and a mild tangy finish. Thin-medium body, fairly astringent. Okay. Cherry not so evident.

Bottle, shared at my 10K rating celebration. Nose of caramel, cherry, vinegar, yogurt, vanilla. Hazy orange-amber with lace. Nice balance, medium sourness, fruit seemed a bit faded at first, but came through better as it warmed up. Bit of lactic creaminess. Smooth and crisp.
Bottle - a bit disappointing - no nose to talk about - not sour enough - not enough cherry flavour - good quality and subtly complex brew but needs amping up.

Amber color and still with a tart and yet boozy aroma. The taste is quite sour and acidic. A simple straightforward sour but enjoyable. Its a shame these 375ml bottles are so pricey in Japan or Id drink them more often.

375mL bottle from Carwyn Cellars. Batch no 4
Body is a dirty red stained golden colour - looks beautiful from afar - with dense white head.
Yeah righto, its funky - whiff of acetic acid & ethyl acetate straight up hits me for six upfront, I recompose myself and the aroma reveals hard cheese, yoghurt, sour dough bread starter, amongst some vinous red fruit, cherry pip & oaken toast character.
Theres good weight here, and a tremendous, slightly ropey, vinous acidity - sort of akin to a young Pinot Noir in some regard - tannic too, the texture is something intriguing.
Immensely complex palate - heady acetate notes, mature washed rind, panicked horse locked in a stuffy stable, grapefruit rind/pith, Pinot Noir-esque cherry, old charred oak, blackened ripe tomato (?), sort of an unripe raspberry, blue cheese, some cut dried herbs (i dunno, lavender!?). Bracing acidity, very long on the finish yet so very easy to drink.
This is quite marvellous really - every once of my winemakers mind wants to tell me this is a nightmare, but it tastes so good!

The Final Beer of my #6000 celebration (#13 of 13 - six beers on either side of 6000 and the milestone itself). Deep clear, but ever so slightly muddied ruby and almost violet hued body with a thinnish, fast-dying tan head, only about a centimetre tall. Aroma of cherries, sour grapes, oak, cedar, dry grass, funk, brett, lactic acid and a ton of mouthwatering soured fruit notes - very nice smelling and complex! Light-bodied; Biting acidic sourness up front with a lot of fruit elements, but citric acid is noticeable along with a very smooth cherry sweetness along with some raspberries, but the sour flavours hit the tongue first and leave it very nice. Aftertaste shows a bit more of a nuanced flavour with dry oak, cedar and funk noticeable, but the cherry sweetness hits through and the sourness and funk are the strongest - all derived from soured fruits and some light oak notes. Overall, a very enjoyable beer with a great sour flavour that ends nicely, slightly dry, but mouth-watering and making you immediately have another sip - a great example of the style and well worth trying if you can find it, even if you dont like the style, since its a prototypical example of it. I sampled this 37,5 cL bottle purchased from Whole Foods in New York (Columbus Circle), New York on 19-December-2015 for US$11,99 sampled at home in Washington on 31-March-2017 as Beer #6006, the #13th and last of my celebration for #6000!

A 375ml bottle, Batch No.4, bottled in May 2015. Poured into a Lost Abbey teku glass. It was a clear copper amber colour with a one finger off white head that dissipated quickly while leaving sparse lacing. Aromas of cherry, hard candy, wine and barrel. Tastes tart, sour cherry, red wine, acidic, vinegar and oak. Dry, medium bodied with moderate to high carbonation. Overall this was nice and refreshing with good tartness. Would be even better with even more cherries and perhaps slightly less acidity.
Sour cherries, some acetic acid, unripe apples, oak on nose; ripe melons with lighter side of caramel, medium sourness (lactic acid with a spike of acetic).

January 22, 2017. Bottle at home, batch no 4. 
Unclear orange amber with a small frothy off-white head. Aroma is fruity and vinous with sour cherries, light vinegar, lemon, grape skins apricot skins, oak, light sweetness with some stone fruit notes. 
Taste is sour, fruity, very light sweet. Medium bodied, dry, average carbonation. Finish is quite intense sour and dry with vinegar, lemon juice, cherries, light vinous. 
Nice one, fruity and sour but not over the top.
Bottle. Hazy orange amber pour with a small white head. Aroma is cherry, vinous notes, funk. Dry and tart flavor, fruity, cherry. Medium body with high carb level. Nice.

33 cl bottle, Batch No. 4. Murky amber-orange with small white head which dissipates to nothing. Nose is red berries, lacto yeast, acetic, vinous, vinegar, oak, barnyard. Taste is mildly tart, cherries, oak, bready-grassy yeast, vinegar. Medium body, average carbonation. Dry, tart finish. Excellent example of the style.

Bottle (Batch 4) shared at the Dec 2016 Shrewsbury Beer Exchange Group meeting in Chez Sophie. Cheers Simon for this sour puss of a beer. Poured a cloudy orange/amber, full off-white crown. Aroma was sour cherries, as was the taste: acidic and tart from start to finish.

Hazy deep rosey colored with a fast dissipating head. Deep rosey tart aroma with cherries and wood and funky acidic tartness. Pretty sharp sourness on the flavor with bright red wine tones and oak and cherries and a smooth earthy sour funk on the end. Slightly almost too tart but very richly red wine and cherryish.

Bottle shared @ monthly tasting, Chez Sophie, courtesy of SImon F. Pours a misty orange-amber, foamy off-white head. Aroma is sour berry fruit, cherries. Taste is crisp lacto, tangy cherry, some vibrant acidic vinegar. Tangy.

Batch 4. Big fizzy head like on a clear brownish red pour. Big cherry aroma. Pretty clean with some old wood and just a touch of funk. Maybe s bait of raisin. Extremely start. Cherry jolly rancher flavor with a dry finish
Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer.

Bottle from Kris Wines. Batch number 4. Colour is rich rusty orange to brown, cloudy, with a medium beige head which dissipates to nothing. I know there are some who dont like American sours, but when they get it right I love them. Nose is big lactobacilius sour, tart, bitter, aged apple cider, red apple skins, white wine vnegar, brown oxidised apple flesh, white apple sweetness. Taste is massive hit of lactobacilus sour and tartnesss but backed up by a nice full body of apple cider sweetness and tartness, funkiness, white vinegar, malt vinegar. Clean lines, not much funk in the nose but full flavoured.

375ml bottle (says batch no. 4). Pours pinky orange with no head and nice and fizzy. Aroma is tart, white wine and bread. Flavour is tart grape and cherry with a dry sour dough finish. The cherry doesnt lead as it does in a kriek lambic, it just adds a subtle note and some extra fruitiness.

0,375l bottle at home. Bottled May 2015. brown / redish light hazy color, small off-white head. smells of vinegar, vinous, some funk, light wood, light glue, nutty, marzipan, light vanilla, some cherry notes, lovely smell. full body, medium carbonation, slick mouthfeel. tastes citric, light vinegar, light funk, nutty, vinous, bit glueish, light cherry notes. finishes rather dry and medium sour with notes of vinegar, some cherry notes and a bit nutty. very nice one, lovely smell, taste is good but lacking a bit towards the finish, overall lovely beer.
375 ml bottle. Pours an orange mahogany color with no head. Aromas of vinous old wood and tart cherries. Flavors of same with additional green oak and cherry skins. Tart and funky. Nice.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2017 Rami Rami is drinking a Dogpatch Sour by Almanac Beer Company at BierCabMocno kwasne w owocowy sposob, limonkowo-winogronowy? gdzie te wisnie? Dzikosc pod kontrola, nie dominuje, jakies serowe nutki. Bardzo bardzo rzeskie o dziwo. Klasa. choc dziwne jak na flandersaOcena potraktowana skryptem do przeliczania ocen (uzgodnienie UT/RB).

35cl bottle. Clear copper pour with a thin off-white head with poor retention. Notes of cherries, caramel, blue cheese, apple vinegar and tons of macerated cherries. Some vanilla and oak barrel, especially in the aroma. Medium body and carbonation with a very tart and fizzy finish.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2016 Bottle. Pours an orangish-red color with white head. Sour, red wine, cherry, currant aromas. Sour, cherry, red wine, berry, vinegar flavors. A little more intensely sour than I typically prefer, but quite enjoyable.
Bottle. Cloudy dark orange red color. Thin white head. High sourness, medium bitterness, low sweetness. Aroma is wood, cherries, barnyard, spices.

Red brown in color, as expected, and alomst no head. Aroma is sour with clear notes of the added cherries.
Very acidic and sour tasre and once again with clear notes of the cherries. Red wine barrel aging can be a trap, but in this case it works, and the slightly tart red wine notes really shine through.
On tap at St. Augustines on Rare Beer Tap Takeover. Sour, cherries, tart, bready. Pleasant.

Bottle enjoyed at home - Nose is very much like wine, with slight cherry, vanilla, toffee and caramel on the aroma. The flavor is very much sour with cherry, vanilla, bread and light caramel as well. Its good.

Vinøs nese, kirsebær, vanilje, toffee og lett karamell. Smaken er sur med kirsebær, vanilje, brød, lett karamell.

19.06.2016, 0,375l bottle @ home:
Nice slightly bubbly-creamy mediumlasting head. Aroma is sour-ish dry, mild vinegar, sour red berries, sorrel, minerals, oak, grass, berry skin, bark, hay. Taste is slightly sour-ish dry, berry skin, sour red berries, sorrel, minerals, oak, mild vinegar, grass, fruit stones, citrus acid. Medium bitterness, sour-ish dry mouthfeel. Nice.

Bottle. Pours a flat amber color with no head. Aroma of sweet and tart cherries, a bit of wine barrel. Intense sour taste, minimal cherry sweetness. Lots of tart pucker in this one. A modest wine barrel influence. Very nice to sip on while catching up on some r&r.

375ml bottle shared with Ace at Havana. Poured a clear brownish amber with a fizzy light beige head. Aroma/flavor is more tart than sour. Notes of leather, dark fruit, figs, sugar, funk and acidity. Solid but not their best sour offering.

As always, almanac hits this one out of the park. Quite tasty and tart, I like this one a lot.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma: balsamico, sour, hey, funk
Taste: green apple, hey, vinegar funk at the end

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, batch 4. Pours hazy pinkish orange, with a small rocky head. Aroma is tart notes of balsamic vinegar, cherry stones and peel, red berries and wooden barrels, as well as leather, tannins, succade and some light funky notes. Full body, with soft carbonation. Flavour is acetic, with tart cherry notes, citrus peel, sherbet and wooden brett, as well as some funky, leathery notes. Lingering acidic finish.
Pours orange to yellow with a nice head, aroma of glue, wood, brett, cherries, flavor is sour with brett, yogurt, lemon, great, medium bodied.

Bottle. Pours reddish amber , almost no head. Aroma: sour, berries, soap sweetness, wine vinegar, Taste: medium sour, salty, berries, woodiness, vine vinegar.Thin + body. Sour long finish. A bit dry. Really nice.

Bottle @ Cafe Albert, Aarhus. Pours dark golden with an small offwhite head. Aroma of sourness, light yeast, wood, wet oak tartness, fruit, grapes, cherry, wine barrels. Flavor is sourness, yeast, wet oak, tart fruit, cherry, wine grapes, oak, light sweetness, hint of vanilla, light vinegar. Medium body, soft to average carbonation, acidic finish. 090416

375ml bottle from Mikkeller webshop. Batch No 4. Reddish amber brown colour, off-white foamy head leaving lacing and aroma of citrus rind, oak, funky, cherry notes. Taste is sour, citric lemon rind, grainy, woody with cherry, funk. Slick mouthfeel, medium bodied, soft carbonation, drying tart finish. Very drinkable.

Bottle
Aroma-barnyard, apricots, plums
Appearance-amber, cloudy, minimal head, 
Taste-heavily sour, light sweetness, lightly bitter, 
Palate-medium body, sticky, average carbonation, long finish, 
Overall-very good
A really interesting and complex sour. There is barrel aged influence, some red fruit, and a light sourness. Delicious.

Bottle. Pours out a pretty cool looking deep reddish color with a small white head. Aroma is tart, cherries, oak, funk, light sour acidic notes. Taste is equally as solid,, tart and lightly sweet cherries, funky basement, acidic tartness, some barrel and lingering cherries.

hazy orange, white head.
Mild aroma, some fruits, some barrel and booze.
Flavor is plenty sourish, citrussy and slightly wild yeasty, faint fruity note. Somewhat more sour and citrussy and less vinegar like than most sour reds ive had. But in fact quite tasty.
Pours deep, clear, ruby-tinged amber into a tulip. Bright white head with good retention recedes to hug rim. Dark cherry funk aromas. Sharp, tart funky cherry front to back. Lasting pith finish.

Batch 2, 2014, sampled in 3/2016. Assertive fruity acidity atop toasty malt. A previous review mentioned sourdough yeast, and thats right on. Ruddy brown. Hints of woody vanilla and cherry. Really solid.

(375ml 2015 bottle from Saveur-Biere) Pours a slightly hazy orange-red colour, very rapidly dissipating big white bubbles, no retention. Aroma is sour, with prominent oak, sharp tart cherry, red wine vinegar, wet earthy Brett, slight balsamico, sourdough yeastiness and lemon juice. Flavour is quite sour-tart with a little sweet (but slightly unripe) cherry in the core for balance, moderate lemon juice, light vinegar, oaky, vanilla, soft marzipan. Finish remains tart with a little oak dryness and earthy Brett. Medium bodied, a bit oily, light carbonation. More of a Flanders red with cherries than cherry driven, wood very present but funk less so. Bit too sour vs. complexity to be really drinkable.

Bottle at home from brewdog sheffieldFull bodied, sharp balsamic vinegar on nose, pretty tart, full bodied, rich and complex, dark cherry fruit, super tart its midway between a rodenbach grand cru and liefmans kriek. Very decent enjoyable sour.

04-MAR-2016, bottle @Ulkløbben meeting, @Mads.
Hazy orange with a low off-white head.
Fruity for a sour brown. Cherry, wood, red wine. Sour. Nice.
Bottle in trade. Nice reddish brown pour. Amazing funky sour cherry aroma. Taste follows, Im loving sours from these guys!

Pours murky copper with a fading head.
Nose shows funk, lemon, soft cherry. Some hints of vanilla and woody oak too.
Massively acidic flavours, with supporting cherry/marzipan sweetness, faint lemon and oak.

Bottle pours a hazy brownish Amber with a large khaki head. Aroma of oak, vinous, Brett, light tart cherry. Taste is very sour, vineager, oak, wild yeasts, light tart cherry. On par with many Kriek style beers, but lacking complexity or originality.

appearance: coppery red, hazy, with a short, fizzy light tan head that vanishes quickly. aroma: sour cherry and raspberry, fairly astringent on the nose, with some woody notes and balsamic vinegar.  taste: bitingly tart and sour, with cherry, raspberry, general stone fruit (mostly underripe), with a bit of oak and a ton of vinegar. finish: lingering tartness, more sour as it warms, also a little bitter, with lasting astringency. notes: I like my sours a little less, um, angry. This was aggressively sour and astringent. Bottle from Sarah for Beerdvent 2015.
From the Bottle at a Halloween party. Lots of sour notes on the nose and the tongue. amazing stuff. Just like a sour should be.

Hazy reddish brown. Nose thick with sour citrus, vinegar, boozy wine barrel, oak, fruit, and light acetone. Flavor is tart, boozy citrus and vinegar with some vinous notes and oak barrel. Somewhat heavy-handed.
Almanac tap takeover at PreFunk Nampa hazy brown with a small light tan head. Woody and earthy sour tartness. I found it fairly aggressive in the sour character and the wood/barrel aging is apparent.

Refrigerated 12.7 oz brown bottle batch 4 poured into a tulip. Clear orange with small off-white head. Aroma is nice tart, medium body, low carbonation, and some lacing. Taste is tart cherries, oak, some red wine, and dry finish.

Bottle from craft beer cellar A: red wine, cherries, red fruits, woody app: hazy copper sparing white head t/p: med body with long acidic finish. Moderate carbonation. Salty. O: really enjoyed it. The barrel aging is easily perceived with the nice fruitiness it makes for a complex beer. The sourness is intense right to my taste.

Pours a bit reddish, on a second look more like copper. Some white foam, not much though. Aroma is quite sour and acidic, you can feel some cherries if you dig deep. Taste is quite straight on sour and acidic. If you let it settle it becomes more approachable, you get some cherry and cherrytree peels. Pretty sour overall, lingering sticky sourness in the end. Nice experience.
Bottle from the Garvie dregs run. Pours amber with a thin white head. Aromas of sour cherry, oak. Taste is sharp, and creamy. Dry finish.
Bottle at craigs. Pours deep orange, nose is funky grape, oak, taste is quite sour, tart cherry, dry, bitter.

This was poured into a tulip.
The appearance was a slight hazy burnt orange to burnt red color with a one finger white foamy head that quickly dissipated and left no lacing.
The smell started off with sour and tart cherries invading some light citrus and a light malty background.
The taste was mostly the same as the aroma. Tart and sour cherries roll into sour to bitter citrus rind all rolling about and feeling out the aftertaste with a sly sour and dry feel in the finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a decent sipping quality about it. Carbonation feels good and right at par for the AWA style. Nice bitter harshness pounds on my tongue, but not overbearing.
Overall, as an AWA, it works, hmmmm, as a Sour Red/Brown ale, Id say I guess it works.

Hazy dark golden, soft ringed head. Nose is peppery sweet, soft creamy cherry. Initial taste is tart, rich sook of sharp citrus and creamy cherry coming through. Carbonation is soft enough and a clean tart punch on a mouthfeel. Finishes clean enough, rich vibrant tart white berry.Bottle, Public Transport Delayed Tasting, Cornelius
Bottle. Amber with little white head. aroma of sour cherry, oak and a touch of fruity vinegar. Taste is funky, fruity, oak, cherry. Dry and very sour. Nice
Pours pink cherry red with a slight white head. Aroma is cherry, raspberry, hay, green apples and s touch of funk. Taste is heavy tart, some lactic, slight cherry tart, cherry sweet, vinous, dry.
bottle at home ... copy ... small white head ... soft funk fruit nose .. long fruit funk ... tart tart fruit ... dry funk fruit ... big funk fruit
Pours a golden amber color with minimal head. Aromas of vinegar, cherries, and some woody notes. Flavors of sour fruit, funk, and foeder.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2016 Sour ale from a bottle bought online. Medium thin but reasonably steady, egg-white, moussy head over a misty amber coloured beer with ochre hue. Complex sweet with sour aroma of passion fruit, sour cherries, strawberry pie, brown sugar, artisanal fruit yoghurt, mouldy orange, brown bread, stewed pear, old sherry, overripe gooseberry, gingerbread, peach, medlar. Sour onset, passion fruit, a ton of unripe stonefruit and redcurrant in the most literal sense of the word, lime too as if youve just bitten into a fresh one, insufficiently tempered with a very subtle apricot sweetishness, softish carbo, smooth honeyish and caramelly maltiness underlying this array of sourish fruits, bit sherryish too, progressing into a finish of strong drying grape-, lime- and redcurrant-like tartness, sherry vinegar-like flavours and a hint of red wine including the woody tannins, but gently so; hops are only structural, as expected from the style. Leaves a long but relatively simple acidity after swallowing with a light woody drought alongside, as if you just poured down a really dry red wine. Interesting, but enjoyed by itself, like I did just now, this seems to fall short a bit in complexity, flavour layers and finesse. It is a good thing American craft brewers try to master sour beer styles, but this is a tad too harsh and straightforward to my palate - and being Belgian, I think I have a good idea of what a good sour beer should taste like. This is a crude onslaught to the stomach and needs a lot more refinement, but in a gastronomical context e.g. paired with a very sweet dessert, I can see this function very well.

Bottle. Hazy amber liquid with small to medium off-white head. Aroma of cherries, wood, lemon, dried fruit, light vinegar and apple skin. Taste is dry and medium sour with notes of cherries, lemon, apple skin and light grain. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Nice!
375ml. Batch 4. Rusty reddish brown. Smells like a bad wine. Made in a bathtub. Taste, thankfully, is completely different. Mildly spour, cherry, oak, lots of fruity wine. Refreshing, low acidity.

Bottle shared by Vindueskigger. Pours hazy dark reddish amber with an off white head. Aroma of red berries, red currants, light popcorn, tart, light vinegar. Taste is very sour, vinous, popcorn, light vinegar, malty backbone.
Bottled. A hazy amber beer with a beige head. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and caramel. The flavor is sour with notes of tart fruits, lemosn and straw, leading to a tart finish.

Bottled. Hazy orange colour with an off-white head. Aroma and flavour of tartness, fruit, spice, yeast and wineous.
37.5 cl bottle. Pours hazy orange with a small off white head. Aroma is fruity, slight winous. Sour, wineous. Tart and dry. Citric, solid fruity and tart finish.
Bottle. Pours reddish golden. Aroma is sour, fruity, champaign. Taste is sour cherry with a dry wine finish. A lot of carbonation. Good sour.

Draught at Watering Hole. Big sour punch to the face, sour cherry, notes of berries, lemon juice, decent funk, long sour finish. Lovely sour brew, almost too punchy but still very enjoyable in glass size.

Ive had a penchant for sour these last couple of weeks, and although Ive been drinking other styles, Ive been craving these. Breakfast and lunch go by and I realize that all I want to do with my afternoon is find a great sour style and just savor it. This is my choice for tonight, and as soon as I open the bottle, I know Ive made a good choice.
- As I pour the beer, I bend a little aggressive to drive the aroma up and out of the glass; tonight, maybe Im just a little greedy. The red wine and cherries are distinct, but the lactic acid is a force to be reckoned with, the tartness of the combination is mouth-watering even before I can wrap my lips around the first sip.
- The flat, red-amber of the body is not capped, but a ring of cream-colored, soapy foam girdles the inside of the glass, becoming thicker with each movement and subsiding again. Even as I lift the beer to my lips, the head rises; tipping to drink coats the walls of the glass with a wet, heavy foam that sinks back into the beer in a matter of moments.
- A jaw-cracking sour fiends on the soft flesh of my mouth, assaulting the underside of my tongue with acidic fruits and oak-laden wine. A thin line of goose bumps runs down my spine, reaching out to trace my shoulders to fingertips. Damn, I needed this. My mouth soon adapts to the blitzkrieg and the oak and lactic acid become much more obvious in both the aroma and flavor.
- A clean, dry finish, full of woody earth and sweet dough is a welcome experience, and since this is readily available, Ill be making this a go-to sour red in my cooler.

Bottle at Eric, thanks Isabel! Reddish brown with small off white head. Aroma is sour, funky, wood, lactic, acetic, fruit and red berries. Taste is sour, complex, fruity, citrus, funky sour lactic and acetic, red berries and cherries leading to a funky sour finish. Really nice!

37.5cl bottle from The a Bottle Shop, London. It pours a hazed plum color with minimal beige head. Aroma is sour and winey, with lemon juice, funk, basement and tart cherries. Taste mouth puckering acidic with tarte red berries, basement funk, lemon juice and light Greek yoghurt. Nice white wine note, no booze. Light to medium bodied with lively carbonation. Overall, very tasty.
Bottle. Thanks to someone, (please let me know who it was). Nice, biscuits, sweet, cherry tart, nice texture, spritzy, white wine. Its nice. Light sourness. Cherry finish. Good stuff
Highly vinegar scent with a touch of sour cherries. Orange brown opaque haze unfiltered. Sour and bitter. Makes you pucker up. Taste is overwhelmed by sour.cant give you much. Tap

Bottle from Tanakaya shared at a sour tasting. Pours a brown with a tiny off-white head of foam that lingers for a bit. Oak on the nose with some light cherry aromas. Quite sour on the palate, like an aggressive Flanders red. The cherries are lost in a sea of sour and oak, but still good carbonation with a medium to full body. Finish is sour and lingers with some light vinous character. Not bad.

Thanks to willisread for sharing the bottle!

Poured into a wine glass showing light caramel brown and sparse white foam. 

The nose shows light and barely perceivable cherries. 

The palate is highly carbonated and light bodied. Highly tart such that any other flavors are barely noticeable.
Hazy blood orange color. The cherries are pronounced with oak. The mouth is sour and overwhelms the cherries. Some oak is there, but sourness just dominated way too much.
Bottle from Cotteridge Wines; hazy amber pour with a thin white head, aroma has white wine, grape, taste has sweet cherries, some wood tart fruits, white grape, red berries, subtle sourness.

Draught at Stone Liberty Station, San Dieo. "Sour Saturday" during SDBW 2015. Cloudy orange/copper beer with a small offwhite head. Sourish caramel aroma, brett, leather, raisins, spicy notes, hay, funky, some grapes and dough. Sourish fruity flavor, grapes, citrus, funky, leather, yeast notes, spicy notes, grapefruit, earthy notes. Complex and very nice.

Pours a hazy golden brown from the bottle with thin bubbly off-white head. Aroma of lactic acidity, funky earth, woody tannins and dark fruit. Taste is mostly the lactic and fruit, nice lingering acidity. Very nice.
Aging in wine barrels give this beer another layer of complexity. Full of sour cherry goodness that really lingers on the palate. Not lacking for flavour.

Bottle picked up in Napa. Pours a rich, hazy, golden color. Nose has hints of cherries along with the bit of funk that sour beers are known for. Taste is a nice bite of bitter cherries, lingering for just a couple of minutes, begging for another taste. Light carbonation and great, silky mouthfeel. This sour holds together even as it warms a bit, unlike some lesser sours that lose a lot of sour characteristics as they warm. Definitely recommended!

Bottle shared during Scopeys 5K tasting - Croydon, London. Thanks, Bruce! Pours hazy grapefruit pink with a frothy white head. Good tangy berry nose. Light sweet flavor with hints of berry candies, good tart citrus, moderate acidity. Light bodied with average carbonation. Clean on the finish, tart and biting, with lingering sour berries. Nicely balanced overall. Great sour.
On tap at Biercab. Reddish colour with white head. Wine and fruity, yeast aroma. Acidic, wine, fruity and yeast taste, sour. Medium body. Dry mouthfeel.

[7571-20150821] 375mL bottle. Fruity barrel yeast aroma. Clear, red amber body with a quick foamy white head. Sour fruity yeast flavour. Full body is quite tart. Delicious and sour. (7/3/8/3/16) 3.7+
(c/o wilco, w/ him, jercraigs)
Overheard: "We are the Yeasty Bottoms!"

Cloudy appearance. Thin head that receeds almost instantly. Poor lacing. It smells like a cabernet. Some cherry aroma. Aroma makes my nostrils tingle. Very tart. Dry mouthfeel. Definetly sour. Average carbonation. Sour finish. Have not had many sours but this beer has convinced me to try more.

This months "Why the hell did I age this beer so long?! Series" entry comes to you from a batch 2 bottle (I think approaching 3 years old), drunk 9/24/15.Clear rosy-pink body is not the deep cherry red of some cherry beers yet it certainly is not golden. Pink-flecked head atop is initially large but rapidly recedes to cover.Both cherry and grape are represented in the nose, the grape being laced with wood tannin and plentiful lactic notes are present. Quite funky, but all things fairly well-integrated, all told. Obviously, at almost three years, theres not going to be much cherry left, but what is, is still clean and authentic. Malts are quite sparse, with crackers, light biscuits and almost no sweetness. No alcohol or flaws.Very tart up front, with both malic and lactic acids attacking the palate and building up in to an intensely sour finish. Dry wood tannin, tart cherries and light vinousness all tip the scales to the very dry end of the spectrum, to say nothing of the bacterial acidity. Obviously a bit past its prime and whatever maltiness was present is now utterly devoured. Still, the flavors are true and enjoyable and had I been a responsible beer drinker and not aged it, Im sure it would have been incredible.

Bruised grapes, plums, & black cherry with vibrant undercurrents of lemon & lactic acid. A soft floral & perfumy presence flows evenly from start to finish, bringing everything together. Acidic cherry flavor accompanied by lemon, red grape, soured oak, musty wood, & a strong lacto presence. Sharp, snapping carbonation makes for a wonderfully dry finish. I really enjoyed this one.

"Flanders Red (already a favorite style) with a CA twist - I like it! a little lighter than expected in color. The sourdough yeast, cherries, and light oak and wine dominate the aroma and flavor. Moderately sour, very complex. I LOVE the yeast used here. Unique within the style."
Bottle courtesy of Shaftie, thank you sir! Cloudy amber color, white head. Beautiful aroma of funky summer fruit. taste is softly sour fruit, nicely balanced and complex. Delicious.

0.375l bottle. Dark orange body, white head, some sediment in the bottom if the bottle. Aroma and taste of mostly lemon zest, with notes of toast and grapes. I cant notice any cherries (the label says they used some). Very sour beer.
Sour as hell. Faint cherry somewhere in there. Smells nice but the yeast is not supported enough by anything else. Not really feelin it.

Bottled: Initial frothy head that faded quickly leaving no lace. Great sourd cherry and biting wine vinegar overtones. Moderate tannic oak and very faint barnyard. Aggressive mouth feel in this very American sour ale. I dig this and think it is about perfect right now.
375ml bottle. Poured a hazy golden color with a white head. Cherries, wood, and some vinegar.

Aroma of acidic grapes, black cherries, acidic vinegar, cherry pie, biscuit and grain malt. Murky copper appearance with no foam. Taste is heavily sour with notes of cherry pie, oak, vinegar, pie crust, biscuit, grain malt and juicy wine grapes. Overall, another fantastic sour by Almanac. Really nice juicy qualities with a strong sour taste. A rating.

#400

Batch #2

P: Cloudy, gelatin almost, apricot body with a thin effervescent white cap. 

S: Tart sourness with a dirty fart bubbling in the background. 

T/M: Funky mouth puckering sourness. Aged granny apple cider and rotten wood. Brings tear jerkers to mind. Astringent and vivacious feel. 

O: My teeth hurt from this sour monster.

Serving type: bottle

Bottles (Batches 1 & 2) thanks to the local group for sharing. Both poured amber color with almost no head. Aroma are very similar. Cherries, basement funk, lemon candy, and vinegar. Batch 1 tasted very sour. More than I like. Batch 2 was a little easier to drink and less sour. Sour cherries and barnyard mostly. Tart lemon candy in the finish. Solid sour.

Bottle: The aroma consists of moderate sour cherries, light lemon, sweet tarts, and a touch of vinous notes. It pours a transparent golden-orange with a small white head that quickly fades to almost nothing. The flavor starts with moderate sour cherries. The finish has moderate-heavy sour lemon an light vinous notes. Its light bodied with light-moderate carbonation.

375 ml bottle. Pours a hazy orange-ish light brown color with no head and no lacing. The aroma is ripe with sour cherries and some light dumpster funk. The taste features more sour cherries, but not quite as bold as the nose foreshadowed, the malt base is a tasty cookie/biscuit mix. The palate is medium and smooth, but the carbonation is distractedly weak. Finishes long and sour. Overall: Not the best sour in this city.

Sample at Kurtkeller 014: Almanac-tastic 01 on 06/27/2014. Murky orange color with a thin white head that dissipates quickly to a spares outer ring. Spotty lacing. Aroma of tart cherries, oak and yeast. Medium-bodied with flavors of sour cherry, vinous oak and doughy yeast. The finish is tart with a lingering cherry and oak aftertaste. Good beer all around.

Bottle pour on the bus during RBWG. Amber pour with a small head. The nose is moderately tangy. Some balsamic vinegar and mashed forest fruits. Cherry comopte. The taste is less aggressive. Slightly sour raspberry tart. Earthy cranberry bog. Soft lactic bite. Medium body, soft carbonation. Very tasty.
375 mL bottle. Light amber with a small off-white head that vanishes. Aroma is of cherry, fig, vinegar, funk, vinous notes. Taste is of cherry, berry, vinous, light oak, wine vinegar, and sour.
Bottle. The smell is tart, funk, vinegar, fruit, fig, and grapes. The taste is tart, wine, fruit, sour, and nice. The look is golden to orange color, thin white head, and hazy.

Poured from bottle to glass. Orange hue with fizzy white head that dissipated immediately. Aroma is lactic, acetic, straw, cherries. Mouthfeel is great with a light body and sharp carbonation. Taste is dry sweetness throughout with a sharp sourness in the following and extending through. Overall this is a great brew!

Pours a hazy red/brown. Aroma of sour lemon and cherry with some hints of oak and bread in it. Taste was sour cherry, lemon, oak, and earthy. Very tart and bitter. Not my favorite, but certainly not terrible.

12.7oz bottle, thanks to caterwaul for sharing! Totally cloudy amber color. Virtually no head or lace. Medium to bigger body. Smooth, kind of soft / crisp lighter carbonation. Kind of sticky finish. Light effervescence. Pleasing texture. Awesome bigger cherry aroma, and some wood. Light lactic kind of creamy edge to it. Satisfying bigger sour taste. Close to puckering. Very satisfying, assertive sour brown. Much more sour than your typical "flanders", though.
Pours dark orange with a small white cap of foam. Aroma of tart cherries, wild yeast, and sour candy. Taste follows with a dry bitter finish.

Pour out of 375 mL bottle. hazy reddish pour with white head, aroma brought notes of sour lemon, oak, alctic, nice berry/cherry notes into a bit of slight bready notes. Taste is a mix of sour cherry, beryr, lemon, tart fruit into some lemon, oak, earth, finishing fairly tart, slightly sweet. Very nicely done.
Smell of funky cherry, lacto. Flavor was sour, moderate fruit, funky. Overall ot was a good sour
Share with bmmillsy. Pours cloudy peach orange. Aroma vinegar, cherries, fruity. Excellent. Great tarty sour beer. Super cherry tartness, lemon, some type of wood (faint).

A- pours a deep amber color with little to no head.

S- extremely tart, apple, vinous notes

T- Deep tartness all the way through, cherry, green apple, wheat, light peach

M- medium bodied with ample carbonation.

D- awesome sour. Absolutely phenomenal. Well rounded but extremely sour right from the get go.
Bottle from Rob - thanks! Murky orange pour with minimal head. Awesome aroma of tart cherries, wine, and some leathery funk. Nice tart on the tongue but not too puckering. Really nice.

Pour from a 12oz bottle. Sour, lactic nose with a little funk in the background. Murky light orange pour with a white head. Bright snappy lactic taste with subtle cherry and dark fruit. Refreshing and nice.
Sour yeasty deliciousness. Pours Pink with very small head. Flavors that jumped out at me were Sour Grapes, Dough, and Cherries.

This one poured a lighter red cololr with a white head. Aroma was of sour cherries, pale malt, and lactic acid. Flavor was similar, fairly straight forward, a bit mild on the cherries. But fairly tasty.
Poured orange and amber. Smelled of cherry and hints of sulfur. The palate is overwhelmed immediately; extremely sour. Had a slight alcohol burn.

Poured from a bottle into snifter. Pours hazy gold with almost no head. Cherry tart aroma with hints of wild sour yeast. The taste is very complex with sour cherries and the wine barrels coming through beautifully. Slightly tart with a smooth finish. Great sour ale. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle to snifter (Batch 2). Looks good; a cloudy reddish orange with eggshell head that quickly dissipates into very thin lacing. Smells and tastes of cherries and funk with a tart, lively mouthfeel along with some oak and a vinous presence. Good stuff!
This is a good sour, smells of lactic acid and some fruity notes as well, it taste pretty much like a sour bomb, lots of lacto up front and then there is some fruit sweetness, finish is dry
Bottle split with a couple friends. Pours hazy amber with small head. Aroma is sour cherry, lemon, lactic acid, grape, oak. Medium light body. Quite tart.

Bottle shared thanks to beerman6686. Pours a clear pinkish yellow color. Aroma is of sour fruits, some grapeskin, cherry. Taste is tart and clean. Very well done as I have grown to expect from Almanac.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2014 tepid honey, no head. Celery and cherry nose, soft vanilla. Flavor huge improvement, zesty lime across front with uplifting small bubbled carbonation, soft lactic mid with orange and faint honey sweetness in the lightly vegetal, sparkling carbonation finish.
Very sour on finish, citrusy with some apricot. Some plum, fizzy carbonation. Some bretta. Cloudy orange without much head or lacing. Bottle thanks to Shaftie at Epic Sour Tasting.
Awesome, awesome beer. Sour and tart, reminded me of a warhead candy or something like that. Funky with a full body. Please give me more!!!!
From a bottle shared at the DC Epic Sour Beer Tasting. Thanks Shaftie! Pours a cloudy gold with a thin off white head. Tart apple flavors. Very sour finish.
Bottle. Poured a light hazy ruby color with a off-white head. Aroma is notes of light sour fruits. Flavor is light fruit, plenty of sour notes. Pretty tasty. Nice and funky. Liked it.

Thanks to Shaftie for sharing this! Really lovely combination of tart cherry, sourdough (which I absolutely adore), and unripe plum, a bit of cheesecloth. Clean, nicely balanced for the style which can often be overdone. Really impressed with all 3 of the Almanac sours Ive had today, with this being the 3rd.

375ml bottle in a tulip. Pours pinkish amber with an off-white head. Aroma of tartness, wine and oak, light cherry notes, and some pale and light notes of caramel malts. Flavor the same with the tartness and beer up front and the cherries providing a nice finish. Average texture. Almanac just keeps killing it with their fruited sours.

Hazy orange/rose pour with a white head. Aroma is very acidic upfront with notes of wine and oak coming through. Flavor is pretty sour on the first sip but settles into nice flavors of cherry and wine notes. A respectable offering.

Shared 12.7 oz. bottle poured to snifters showing a hazed, orangey/rose color, with a light & diminishing, soft white head & lacing. The nose was yeasty, tart cherries, citrus as ruby red grapefruit, with an odd hint of celery? The taste was very tart, nearly sour, vinous, & dry. Light bodied, but quite a tasty, palate cleanser.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2014 Pour is a murky deep orange with a thin white head. Nose has a bit of wood, dusty with a hint of mushroom and a light cherry. Very sour, a bit acetic, strong carbonation and a light body. Dusty brett and faint mushroom funk with some tart unripened cherry. Assertive sourness and some acetic acid in the finish but not much.

Pours a dark golden-amber. Interesting looking beer. Small eggshell head, minimal lacing. Aromas of tart cherries, light oak, musty grapes and funky breads. Taste is moderately tart upfront. Cherries, oak, light sourdough. The body is slightly heavy...giving a decent sweetness. Finishes nice and long, allowing the flavors to resonate.

Bottle. Pours amber with a small, loose off white head that quickly fades and leaves no lacing. Nose is funky and woody, vinous, light citrus fruit, vinegar. Taste is moderately tart and lightly sweet. Flavor is acetic with some cherry skin, wood, and a little sourdough bread in the finish. Medium body Opens up nicely and shows some subtle complexity. Very nice.

Pre-DLD bottle share at Hampton Inn. Pour is hazy golden with a small white head. Aroma is huge sour - lemon peel, citrus, port, hay. Flavor is similar with some dark fruit and wood added in an attempt to balance out the sour.
Nom nom nom. Loving this series! Nice and funked out tart style sour from Almanac. Cherry is present but well built in. Barnyard is plentiful, not overpowering. Damn good beer.
375ml bottle. Nice fruity and decently sour cherry brew, funk like alot of these almanac beers.

Bottle thanks to Ontape ! Pours a ripe golden peach color with a finger of fizzy foam. Nose is full of funky vinous fruit, syrah grapes, sour cherry, leather, touch of sweet malt and a hint of light toasted vanilla. Palate follows the nose nicely with a good carbonation and layers of flavor. Great balance of funk and sour puckering vinous fruit.
yea this was VERY nice. Tons of complexity. The cherries come out in the background and really add to the flavors in the background. Pretty nice stuff.

Bottle poured an orange amber color with a fizzle of white head. Aroma has mellow sourness, cherry, and a bit of yeastiness. Mouth feel is light and the carbonation on the lower side. Flavor definitely smacks on the sour side, tart cherry, mild barrel wood, and a long tongue watering finish. The malt side is like a half Flanders half golden mix.

Nice cherry sour. Pours golden amber with little head which is odd for a flanders red?. Aroma is light cherry and and heavy lactic sour notes. Taste is lightly fruity with some vinous character and oak.

Soft tawny gold pour with a reddish hue and thin fizzy head. Round cherry notes and a nice acidity with some fruity esters and an almost vitamin-y character. Nice tartness in the flavor with some cherry skins and wood. Moderate acidity.

Bottle to glass. Pours a hazy burnt amber color with a thin rim of off white head. Aroma is a bit mild, but pleasant. Slightly dry, tart, white wine, very little cherry, maybe some sourdough? Flavor is immediately sour, but not overwhelming. Slightly sweet. Lingering oily sourness in the finish. Excellent beer.
Bottle share. Pours a hazy orange. Aroma of wet dog, sourdough, fresh fruit, white wine. Taste is tart and sweet. Super dry finish. Medium-high carbonation. Sticky.
Bottled, poured into a tulip glass. Maybe its just not for me, expected more of the cherry & wine but was just overpowered by the sour.
Brilliant rosy orange pour with quickly fading white head. Aroma is sour oranges, light alcohol, grapefruit. Flavor is tart cherry and citrus, some barnyard quality, vinegar.
Bottle, very good carbonation, vinious, red aroma sour yeast, great funk, lingering sour dough characteristic. Great with dry dry cheese.
Bottle shared at Proof by Tim (thanks!). Phone note: Deep orange slight head. solid strange Aroma bandaid cherry grape musk - locker room socks. Sharp clean even cherry sour. Nice tart. 8.2
Bottle. Hazy ruby pour with tan head. Tart cherry and lacto aromas. Full cherries with tart overtones, oak and vinous hints.

Murky light orange pour, no head. Aroma simialr to Tang orange drink with some light vinegar accents. Solid sour flavor with some roasted notes, sweet tarts, sour cherries, Decently thick mouthfeel. Thanks to Lance for sharing this at Proof Friday night tasting.

Great 12-oz bottle. Foggy, maple blonde-brown beer, not much head. Good sour, fruity/biotic aroma. Sour, but doesnt make your glands tingly behind your jaw. medium body, loses CO2. Kind of one-note. Thanks to Lance @ Proof.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2015 375 mL bottle poured.  Pours a cloudy orange color with a big sour grape and cherry aroma.  Huge sour flavor.  Has to be one of the most sour beers out there, which is probably why I love it so much.  Sour cherry is there, but there is many different sour fruit going on here.  This is exactly what I look for in a sour beer.  One of my favorites.   Love this beer.

Bottle, generously brought across the country by GT2. Thanks buddy. This was a nice, easy drinking, sour red/brown, definitely more in the American style (read: less woody, and a tad more funky). Pretty clean palate with notes of sour cherry, other red fruits, and funky yeast. Nice stuff if not super complex.
From the bottle. Nose is of funk and cherries. Taste is cherries and sour, with just the right carbonation.

Bottle courtesy of hamilton23. Pours a slightly hazy yellow with a white head. Nose is big tartness- citrus, stone fruit, vinous fruit, and some slight cherry. Flavor is similar with stone fruit, citrus, tartness, vinous character, and cherries. So much going on inside this one sour. Light to medium in body and one to ponder, definitely.

Wheaty, earthy, yeast smell, the taste is sour not ripe cherry, citrus, the color is a dull orange. This is a good sour not on the par of some of Russian Rivers sours but its really good. Price point is a little too high, I paid $10 for a 12 oz!
Bottle. Pours hazy gold with a thin white head. Aroma of sour cherry and leather. Taste follows suit and is slightly lactic and acidic. Medium sticky palate with light carbonation. Solid.

Bottle. Hazy orange. Tart funk on the aroma. The taste is lighter than I expected on the sourness and cherry but, is still great. There's a sweet juicy aspect too. Nice bitter, tart notes. The sour feel fades quickly in the mouthfeel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

355 ml bottle at home, from a trade. Pours a clear bronze fluid with a small head that dissappears instantly. Nose is lots of balsamic vinegar, some red berries and a hint of sweet cherries. Taste is lots of acid, some raspberries and cherries. Finishes off with a pleasant sweetness. I expected more but still a solid beer.

Just finished drinking this (Batch #2) and enjoyed it very much. Pleasantly sour/tart with just a hint of cherry and no off flavors at all. I enjoyed this way more than I expected to, and felt that it was priced well. Glad I have another tucked away!

Batch 1 bottle, weve hung on to this one a while. Had it when fresh and by memory it doesnt seem to have developed much. Cherry flavor is big but wild elements are a bit mild. I want more funk, more sour. A Supplication for the same price just blows this away in my mind. I respect the work Almanac does and -- as Ive said before -- will always try their beers... but for me their ceiling tends to be "solid" but not "amazing". Never had a bad one but this stuff is pricey, thats to be expected at this kinda money.

A - pours hazy orangy brown with very little off white head that leaves a tiny ring. S - well it smells like a sour brown. Lemon juice, white wine notes, acetic and citric acid, brown sugar. Some tart dried cherries and bile. M - typical dry biting citric acid sourness common to most almanacs. Sweet palate. Medium light body. Slippery mf. T - the taste show more fruit than the nose. Cherries and red berries and lemon juice. Sweeter palate is reminiscent of a cobbler made withy under ripe berries. There is some nice musty funk, light white wine and apple cider vinegar. End is sweet malty lemons. O - nice sour.

375ml bottle (b1) thanks to bytemesis! Pours cloudy pale pinkish red with thin fading head. Nose is sour cherry, strawberry, acidic, some dank wood, strong funk. Taste is crisp sour funky cherry juice, fruit punch, lacto, vanilla notes. Finish is sour acidic berries, sweet tarts, funk, vanilla, oak. Nice sour.
Light amber pour with white head. Aroma is acidic and fruity. Flavor is nice sour, some berries, tart acidic finish. A tad thin. A very nice offering overall

Bottle split at Scopeys 5K Extravaganza of Oompah Band meets doorbell music, big thanks to the King of Old Street - 15/02/14.
Hazed orange amber with moderate off white spotting/edgework.
Nose is tarte citric fruit, bitter orange, tarte apricot, dank tones, straw.
Taste comprises pithy orange, dank tones, tarte berry fruits, woody booze notes, lemon rind.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close.
Solid sour brown.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle shared at Scopeys 5000th rate. Cheers to Bruce! Pours hazy golden with a nice white rim. Nose is lemon rind, big and juicy citrus, straw and a nice dose of sourness. Seems to have good balance. Taste has plenty of citrus with a heavy handed focus on lemon cheesecake. Nice biscuity presence here. Very clean and crisp and balanced very nicely. Good sour

Bottle on the bus at RBWG. Pours a hazy dark golden/light amber color with a small white head. The aroma and flavor have a tart/sour cherry character, tart berry, wood, moderate acidity, some sweet dark fruits come in as well, background wine barrel notes. Decently drinkable though I dont think I would want a whole bottle myself.
Bottle from backwells, shared with sloppy at club w. aroma of bandaid and hospital...taste is very sour, cherries, and sour grape, pretty good stuffs

Bottle a while back in the Bay. Aroma and flavor was definitely cherry, wine-barrel sour. For an oude bruin-type beer (which I general shy away from), this one had more cherry character and less toasty brown sour, which was really nice. From beginning to end, cold to warm, this one impressed me. One of the best Ive had from Almanac. Excellent beer.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2014 Bottle, thanks to Bruce. It pours hazy amber with a small tan head. The nose is tangy, vinous notes, earth, red grape skin, prune, wood and vanilla in the background. The taste is crisp, tart, acidic, wood, cherry, raspberry, berry yoghurt, tangy fruits and sherbet with a dry finish. Medium body and fine carbonation. Well rounded and rather drinkable. A nice take on the style.
Bottle shared on bus RBWG pours orangish gold. Nose sour and tart, then some sweet fruit late. Taste similar to nose up front, then sour cherry. Late palate sweetness.
Pours a golden orange with no head. Aroma of cherries, oak, vinegar. Taste is cherries and oak. Sour and fruity. Very good.
Draft. Nice sour and sweet aroma of dried cherries and a little citrus. There is also a little funk in there. A nice mellow sour across the palate with a lingering finish.

Another bus beer from RBWG 2014! Reddish orange, thin ring of foam. Smells like cherry and citrus, soney stoney notes, and a whiff of balsamic vinegar. Smooth and lightly acidic palate. Nice notes of fruit and red wine throughout...

Bottle I shared on the RBWG bus tour (LaZoom!). Pours a clear copper. Aroma is in your face acetone, pungent vinegar, and little bit of berry sweetness to round it out. Really good flavor of blackberries and red berries with a sharp acetone bite a a touch of vinegar for depth. Heavily acidic, mildly acetic. More berry notes with bring this to the next level of ridonk.
Bottle at SD Toronado. A very good sour, great drinker, loved the cherries. Great to catch up with at $17.50 plus tip.

Sampled at Eastside Clube Tavern, Olympia WA
Arrives from the tap with a soft amber color and is topped by a 1/4-finger thick, lightly tan colored head. The aroma has a nice, chewy tartness that seems to be a mix of lactic and acetic acidities. There is a backbone of hay like, and a touch of cracker like malt character here, and a general, sort of grassy quality that is a combination of both the malt and the fermentation character. The nose has quite a bit of fruit character to it really, perhaps some tart cherry, a definite sour berry note, and some musty mellon like character as well.

The beer is soft up front, but has a gripping sourness towards the finish. Pretty well carbonated, and the acidity accentuates the prickly nature of this beer. There is a rounded fruitiness here that is a mix of tart pear notes, start fruit, and some tart currant notes. The body has a light fullness to it, this isnt heavy, but certainly is not a beer to quaff a whole lot of either. There is a backbone of wood here that provides some spiciness, a tannic, astringent body accentuating character, as well as a touch of fresh wood flavors.

An interesting beer to try when you are hankering for something sour. It could be a bit more funky, but is pretty tasty overall.
Bottle share thanks to homers. Pours cloudy orange. Aroma is tart, sour. Taste is much of the same. Thanks drewfiss.
Bottle share thanks to Homer321. Pours a hazy, orange color. Aroma of funk, tarty cherry, and citrus. Big sour and tart flavor, lots of sour, more sour and tart, very tasty.

Bottle via trade. Mike, you send this? Pours a slightly hazy gold to red color. Minimal head. Nose is like a tart pie. Taste is similar. A residual cherry flavor that could be mistaken for yeast character. Not overly tart. Very well done

Bottle from George. Thanks buddy! Pours a murky red-orange color with very little head that dissipates to a ring on the glass pretty quickly. Bit sour vinegar aroma with lots of sweet cherries and a hint of brown sugar. Nice nose on this. Flavor is a nice sweet and sour cherry, some yeast funk, lacto. Pretty expected for the style but with a bit more sharp tartness to go along that makes it nicely drinkable. Medium mouthfeel and a bit more body than other sours, and with carbonation on the lower side--just a little prickle. Overall this was enjoyable.

bottle pours medium orange amber, some soapy bubbles on top. nose has sour cherry, wine, oak. taste begins with cherry, undertones of vanilla sweetness. finish has slight funk. light acid burn on the finish. light body. man, really wish I had moar.
Reddish brown pour, standard brown head. Flavors of cherries, balsamic vinegar, roasted malt, juicy and sweet tart on the finish. Another really good beer from Almanac.

Bottle from Tooch4321...thanks Adam! - Pours pinkish amber with a bubbly off-white head. Nose is dry yeastiness, real lightly dry cherry, a whiff of baking spice, Chardonnay, and some mellow oakiness. Taste is still dry, but has more pungent cherries, Chardonnay, and real light oakiness. Thin and slick with mellow carbonation. A little too much wine barrel for me, but its still pretty pleasant.

Batch No. 1, Bottled Autumn 2013. 375 ml bottle into a tulip glass. Pours a clear red hued body with minimal white edging. Moderate amount of lacing. Aroma is bright sour cherries and acetic acid. Finishes with some caramel, oak and an odd astringency. Smells really nice, almost jammy with a large barrel presence. Taste is sour cherries into some vinegar, brown sugar, and vanilla. Smooth and almost light. A lingering sweetness but it finishes fairly dry. Mouthfeel is a tad thin. Overall this is a very good Flemmish with loads of cherries and barrel.

Multiple bottles and on tap. Pours with a hazy golden orange hued body with a scant white head. Aromas are of waxy pedio, deep funk, stewed fruit, cherries. Flavors are sour, somewhat funky, dried fruit, cherries, stewed prunes. Moderate malt. Vinous, medium bodied, lower carbonation.

18th November 2013Hazy deep amber beer with a tidy peach coloured head. Palate is dry and crisp. Nice sourish twang here. Sourish fizzy cherry sweets. Winey tang - grapey. I assumed this would be a red wine barrel but maybe its white wine. LIttle wood. Finishes light and crisp. Very nice.

Bottle from Felipe, thanks! Pours a orange amber with little to no head. Aroma is oak, chardonnay grapes, cherries. Taste is subtle funk, oak, cherries, and white wine. Fantastic. Nice clean finish. Great beer.

A: Murky Orangish/Brown Hue, Passes Mild Light, White Head Ring, Some Lacing

S: Cherry, Plums, Mild Apricot, Mild Apples, Mild Red Wine

T: Deep Cherry, Red Wine, Mild Apricot, Mild Hay

M: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Semi Bitter, Mildly Tart, Mildly Drying

Overall, you really do get a solid presence of the cherries and the red wine barrel separately, which makes this beer great.

Bottle. Copper beer with an off-white head. Cherry and light sour aroma. Cherry and light sour flavor with light earthiness. Medium bodied. Cherry and light sourness lingers with light acetic notes, light tartness, and light earth.

Hazy reddish orange in color... Aroma is merlot grapes, oak, you'd think you were about to have a wine... Flavor is hints of vinegar, acidic, lightly tart with notes of cherry, merlot grapes, oak... Nice, very complex

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

375 ml bottle courtesy of a BA trade. Pours a nicely hazed copper red hue, some pinkish rosey glow with orange copper edges and bottom. Frothy offwhite head is fairly carbonation driven, dies to a smaller ring, laces small. Darker middle, well hazed tapers out to a nice glow. Aromas are nice cherries, sweeter pie cherries meet tart cherry, cherryskin, red and blush wine, decent oak and lactic elements. Lemon, yogurt, gentle toasty and biscuity malt element is softened by firm oak and wine barrel, cherryskin and juice, firmer lactic presence. Some mandarin oranges, cranberry, some decent complexity if a bit sharp at times, fruit punchy feel at others. A mellow to subtle spiciness hits at times after it settles. Initial lighter end of medium bodied, firm tannic oak and red wine meets some cherryskin, decent tart and sour elements. Underlying touches of bread, biscuit, yogurt and firm sourness. A bit sharp, gentle metallic poke. A bit fuzzy,d ry and tannic as we keep moving on. Yogurt, lemony and lactic life. Cherries, red wine, a gentle touch of Rose and blush wine, decent carbonation and spritzy qualities as we round the corner into the back. Dry, tannic and lactic elements are nice, dryt this out into the back. A mellow carmelized and bready base pokes through gently, more of a compliment. Touches of cranberry tartness meet the cherries, red wine has some life, not overly tannic overall, but a lighter, thinner beer allows those elements to show some life overall if that makes sense. This is solid stuff, a touch llighter and lacking cimplexity, but the elements that are there do work well and flow. Perhaps a bit light, a bit sharp at times. The flavors are admittedly quite nice though. Solid entry here.

375ml bottle from Healthy Spirits. Hazy reddish brown. Nice sugary cherries on the nose, touch of near-balsamic sourness, some citrus, light strawberry. Big tart cherry first up in the taste, brown sugar, light golden syrup, musty earthy notes, some spice, big juicy red fruit, mellow citric tartness, light balsamic and woody notes. Lingering tart cherry kick twisted with lemon rind and musty yeast. Medium bodied. Really interesting take on a Flanders Red. Delicious.

Bottle from Healthy Spirits. Pours a golden amber with a thin white head. Aromas of tart cherries. Tastes of lightly tart cherries. Pretty good for Almanacs first attempt at a sour. Looking forward to next years batch.

(Aug. 2013, bottle from City Beer, SF - Batch no. 1) The colour of this one is very mesmerizing; like a very early orange-red sunrise seen through a fair fog. The aroma is extremely saliva inducing - so sour, you get the wood and the sour cherries - the word "spontaneous" pops up hard. The taste; insanely sour, followed by by discrete wood and slight sweetness. Like a very sour red wine with sourdough bacterias. Not too complex, but heavenly tart!
hazy orange. Sour tannin on the nose. Almost a vinegar quality. Nice and sour, without being a killer. Really nice oak character.
On draft a Pizza Port Carlsbad. List of cherries all over this beer in the aroma and taste. Well-balanced!

Bottle shared by hoppypocket. Beautiful hazy amber pour with off-white head and decent lacing. Aroma is rather discrete for an american sour with oak, light red wine, cherries. Flavors are well integrated. Brown sugar complements the red fruits sourness. Rather full bodied. Although there is some caramel/brown sugar notes, it lacked sweetness to be considered a good example of the Flanders Red style. Although, it is not very sour nor vinegary compared to most attempts at the style from US brewers.

Bottle (375 ml). Shared by Hoppypocket, thanks! Slightly hazy golden/orange with a small fully lasting beige head and good ever lasting lacing. Aroma is of cherries with light winey notes, peaches/apricots, oak and caramel. Taste is also of cherries, oak, caramel, light wine, peaches/apricots and light vanilla. Medium body. Moderate carbonation. Slightly dry finish. Good Sour. Not sure this is a perfect example of a Flander Red, but its definitely a good Sour Ale with Cherries. The barrel treatment is subtle but effective. Good!
Sampled at GABF 2013. Pours a hazy gold with some interesting orange head. Nose is sour, vegetal, rhubarb, orange rind. Flavor is malty, herbal, orange pith, rhubarb, some acid. Acetic finish.

GABF 2013. Pours a reddisho orange appearance with a white head. Funky, tangy black cherry, vinous, raspberry, barnyard aroma. Really easy drinking flavor with flavor of sour cherries, funky fruits, light vinegar, and a touch of caramel. As I remember, jcnielsen didnt particularly care for it, but Im kind of regretful that I didnt go back for more pours.
375 ml bottle thanks to Jay. Orange red color. Tangerine. Apricot. Little bit of cherry. Little bit of Zinfandel. Damn tasty and complex.
GABF 2013. Deep orange. Nice carbonation. Terrific funky sour nose, some stone fruit flesh. Great tart finish, very balanced and refreshing. Not as long or complex as #3 or #4.
Bottle. Pours reddish orange with white head. Nose and taste of wild yeast, tart cherry, oak, wine, ripe berries, pink grapefruit and very citric nectarine peel. Medium body. Light acidity.

Pours dark orange, minimal head.

Smell ripe berries, tangerine, citrus.

Taste sour lactic lemon zest and funk.

Medium bodied. Coating and refreshing.

Very good.

Thanks to bu11zeye for sharing this bottle. Pours a hazy orange color with a white head. The aroma is full of cherry and toffee. The flavor has some strong cherries with a medium amount of tartness. I also get some toffee and biscuit malt. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Very nice sour.

Bottle at home with friends. Pour is clear orange with a small white head that quickly dissipated. Big sour aroma - green apples, pears, a touch of cranberry, raspberries, and lightly vinegary. Taste is tangy, green apples, light strawberry, peaches, raspberry, somewhat oaky, and tannic with a big sour finish. Light body with soft carbonation. Really nice stuff.

The beer appears orange and hazy with a quarter inch or so of off-white head. My wifes is significantly redder and darker. The aroma brings wine barrels, oak, cherries, yeast, farmhouse funk. Lovely flavor with wine character leading the way. Prominent cherries with cherry juice and oak. Light to medium in body with a mild puckering finish. Terrific. I would really like to have this again.

Pours a light brown, cloudy with almost no head. Aromas of musty cherry, oak, perhaps a whiff of wine. Taste is semi-sour with a hint of sweet cherry. Pretty creamy. Finished sweet and sour like the McDonalds sauce. Pretty meh. Would have liked a heavier lactic component with a huge dose of funk, but it just wasnt there.

Tangy wood darker fruit balsamic with definite cherry caramel malt sweetness is here and there. Brown pour thin head. Flavors of tart cherries balsamic wine barrel notes caramel. Musty basement barrel aged notes . Well carbonated. Less sharp an acidic then the farmers reserve. If you ain't first you're last. 

"Meh" (Jon, 2006).

(375ml bottle, courtesy of Errl) Pours a hazy golden body with a small white head. Aroma of cherry, vinous, balsamic, caramel, and vanilla. Flavor of vinous, cherry, berries, grass, oak, and raspberry.
Beady lace, hazy amber color. Mature sour yeast aroma; cherries atop oak. Oaky and balanced on the palate. Crisp, drinkable, really nice. Damn, Almanac is kicking ass these days.

Bottle from The Davis Beer Shoppe. Pours orange amber with a slight, transient beige head. Aroma is sour fruit and sour malt. Med body or nearly. Flavor is that sour brown Flanders thing. It really is. Cherries come through. It seems to fit near the middle of sour browns. It finishes reasonably sour cherry with some sour malt. Just excellent.

Pours out ruby .. . Mild foam head, good lacing .. . Solid tartness, cherry, and sweetarts .. . Medium mouth .. . Full finish .. . Nice beer, would drink it again 

.. . . Theres no such word as Melonology
Received in a trade with bytemesis and shared at Kennys tasting. Hazy and dingy golden. Nice spur. Somewhat vinegar but more than that. An interesting sour. Vinous notes.
(375 bottle) clear rich orange, fine off white bubbles. Nose of strawberry, raspberry, cherry, bits of caramel. Taste of lightly tart fruit, raspberry , barrel, nice tart linger.

Bottle through trade, dark orangish amber pour with minimal head. Big earthy and woody vinous aroma with some subtle cherry blended in. Taste is cherry and some red wine character, drys the palette, big tartness that lingers, solid.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle thanks to Raiders707. Pours hazy red with small white head. Nose is sour cherries, with funky earth notes, straw, grass, and dirt. Taste is mildly sour with some cherry flavors, but the oak and wine dominate the fruit. Finishes tart and dry with some fruity funk.

Draft. Pours a semi hazy amber, with a white head. Dry cereal malt, mildly sweet cherries, light lemon tartness, moderate acidity, and crackers. Decent, but didnt wow me. Well restrained and balanced.

(375ml bottle) In-person trade with Blomster. Pours a thin,white frothy head atop a cloudy, sediment filled deep orange body. Nose of sour cherries. Quite a bit sweeter than other sour beers yet not cloying. Great flavour yet the sourness is oddly shortly lived through the finish. Good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPod

Draught @ Brouwers Café: &nbsp Amber, a little dark and dirty, faint haze, thin to moderate frothy off-white head, spotty lacing. &nbsp Tart nose, a little mealy, slight immature cherry and woodiness on the nose. &nbsp Noticing right away a cereal like aftertaste on this one. &nbsp Very light to moderate, tart, almost sour, but with a very much mealy or cereal like background. &nbsp Yeah, very moderate for the style. &nbsp A little dry. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate. &nbsp Finishes with a lingering cereal/mealy tartness. &nbsp Moderate example, good, but wished it were a little cleaner on the finish.

The beer appears orange and hazy with a quarter inch or so of off-white head. My wifes is significantly redder and darker. The aroma brings wine barrels, oak, cherries, yeast, farmhouse funk. Lovely flavor with wine character leading the way. Prominent cherries with cherry juice and oak. Light to medium in body with a mild puckering finish. Terrific. I would really like to have this again.
375 mL. Excellent sour reminiscent of Supplication from RR. Just the right amount of sweetness I like in an american sour brewed in this fashion.

375 ml bottle shared by bsuedekum- thanks again, Blake! Pours a hazed orange-gold, a bit on the darker side of the spectrum, with a small off-white ring for a head. Aroma of oak, sweat, apple skins, leaves, spice, cherries, grapes, and sourdough. Flavor of sour candy, oak, apples, grapes, caramel and dry malts, cherries, and some light bready funk. Light-medium bodied, with a dry, sour mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Very nice Flanders red ale.

Bottle to stange
Strong sour cherry, lemon, candy floss, light yeast. Deep orange and cloudy, thin white creamy head. Taste is sour apple, lemon, and yeast.
Poured from 12 oz bottle. Cloudy dark orange color. Sweet fruity aroma. Tart cherry flavor. Haven't had many sours and never had a good impression, but I like it

12.7 ounce bottle purchased at The Davis Beer Shoppe. Batch #1. The aroma on this is quite tart and funky. Nice acetic character, along with a little underlying sweetness. Nice, complex nose. Moderately transparent golden-orange body with a small, quickly dissipating whitish head. Starts with a nice sweetness. Becomes rather tart in the middle and end with a bit of an acetic cheesiness. Really nice and drinkable. Immediately, sharp, sour, and carbonated, but as this breathes, it becomes quite drinkable. Cherries are a bit of an afterthought, but tasty nonetheless. Similar to Supplication, and thats a good thing.

Bottle from Windy City shared with Vinny, Frank and Andrew. Pours a light brownish amber body with no head, some minor lacing. Aroma is nice funk, sour fruit - cranberry and grape. Mouthfeel is medium with lots of oak, sour fruit and general funkiness. Very nice sour.

Bottle shared by jimbo, pours hazy brownish copper, with small to medium head, aromas of cranberry, russian river sour, lactic funk, sugar and big oak presence. Puckery and refreshing. Medium body. Not bad, but nowhere near the other almanac reserve series.

Man this is what I look for in a sour. Delicious! Their other beers I havent been too happy with but this one is great. Cloudy golden color. Very distinct tart and barrel flavors. I tastes sooo good. That sourdough yeast is the bomb. I am blown away by this beer. Tart lemon/cherry, apple cider vinegar. Touch of honey. No light sour stuff here. Faint whiskey finish.

From bottle share at Syb Pig in Boca Raton, FL. Thanks Derek! WOW! Pours a deep red with thin white head into a small snifter. BEAUTIFUL color! Smells of raspberries, cherries and apples with a slight acidic (vinegar) smell. Taste is very fruity with raspberries, cherries, cranberries, and an acidic finish like vinegar. Slightly sweet, yet tart. Light body, medium carbonation. Dry finish. I LOVED IT!!

Pours a gorgeous red hue. Smells like pineapple upside down cake and wood. Cherries, cranberries, and barrel, complex, changing as it warms to lighter fruits such as raspberries. A nice light body married to a sturdy acidity thats balanced just right. This is a beautiful beer, I look forward to my cellared bottle.
Cloudy orange-amber pour with not much head. Pretty darn tart with some balancing fruity sweetness from the cherries. Complex, balanced, and delicious.

375, corked and baled. Thanks j! Pours a cloudy medium amber with no head. Huge tart vinous cherry and light balsamic nose. Creamy medium body with soft carb. Vinous, cherry, soft minerally mid palate. Mild tart finish.

Bottle from Healthy Spirits. Pours cloudy amber with a modest off-white head and a sour cherry aroma. There is a complex flavor that includes light malt, cherry, oak and some yeast esters. Quite delicious.

On draft at Caps & Taps. It pours a slightly dark orange color with an off white head. The aroma is definitely funky, lightly leathery sour fruit with some sweetness thats appropriate for the style. The flavor is full bodied and sour with light notes of balsamic, orange, leather, tart berries. Good balance of sweet and sour. Funky finish. Top notch sour brown.

Bottle. Pours hazy reddish amber with a small white head that quickly dissipates leaving a ring that laces decently. Aroma is tart cherry, lemon, woody, touch of funk, vinaceous. Flavor is initially sweet and medium tart, fair amount of astringency that fades into a dry, vinous finish. Astringency fades with time as the beer breathes. Very nice beer, could benefit from a bit more time in the bottle. Not quite as complex as supplication, for example.

Looks like peach juice
Smells like a mix of apricots and pears
Wow. Theres this very fruit Granny Smith and pineapple taste. Very tart and acidic. Hint of blackberries. Like a sour fruit salad
Deep golden color with dry tart cherry aromas. Amazing dry tart sour cherry taste gets you right in the jowls. Refreshing and leaves your palate ready for more.

Draft at chuck's. pours murky orange-brown - looks a little gross but smells tasty. Aroma of cherries, vinegar. Sweet up front, bracing tart middle gives way to aftertaste of sweetened breakfast cereal (the new "mini wheat crunch" comes to mind - probably a combo of brown sugar-like sweetness with grain). Medium-full body, light carbonation, thick and mouth-coating without being sticky. Overall - on the sweet side, and not crazy about the aftertaste, but decent. Stoked about almanac's arrival in WA!

Aroma is moderately acidic with a faint acetic character and moderate wine barrel notes including some tannins. Light cherry note and a moderately strong ester similar to over ripe melons. Its odd as the melon character is stronger than the cherries. Its missing some of the malt character I would expect in some Flanders style beers. 
Pours a cloudy, murky light brown with a pinkish red hue with a somewhat thin, light tan head that recedes fairly quickly to the edges. 
Flavor is lightly sweet with moderate acidity. Moderate barrel quality which comes across stronger than the cherries. Medium light malt character adds some complexity. Light bitterness. Finish is sweet with some tannins and light acidity. The cherry notes really hit mid-palate and do break through everything else but they dont hang around long. Dark fruit complexity isnt up to that of a Flanderss style beer. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium carbonation. I have read of slightly undercarbed bottles but this isnt one of them. Light astringency and low alcohol warmth. 
Overall another enjoyable sour but its not awe inspiring and for a dollar more I think I would rather drink Russian River. I also have a hard time reconciling this with Flanderss style sours as it really lacks the malt character that you would find in a beer true to that style.

Bottle poured into Duvel tulip. Pours a murky orange-brown with tan head. Aroma is part tart and part sweet -- lactic acid, underripe cherries and slight vinegar for the tartness, and butter, honey and melon for the sweetness. Flavor has a unique but slightly understated Rainier cherry character, sweet and fleshy but very obviously not black or maraschino cherry like many other Flemish-style sours have. Theres a significant oaky buttery note throughout, but it isnt really off-putting. It lends a honeycomb aftertaste that competes with cherry pits and fermented strawberries in the finish. Im also getting a sort of milky lactose mouthfeel with a drying sensation, like if youve ever added honey and milk to a cup of tea. I like this beer more and more as I go along. Overall a unique mix of lactic acid and lactose notes with a moderate amount of fruitiness.

Bottle from Stearns. Hazed light amber pour with an off-white head. Decent cherry aroma, some hints of vinegar, and lemon zest. Light oak, vanilla, and grass. Pretty solid aroma. The flavor isnt bad, but not as good as the nose. Cherry, lemon zest, and some oak. Hints of grass and oak. Pretty simplistic. A light sweetness from the fruit.

12oz bottle. Pours a murky brown with a thin white head. Very acidic, lemon, cherries, some funk. Very good sour. I was hoping the cherry flavor would be more prominent though.

From a bottle . The pour is a orange hue with a white head.A fruity sour with a light body and sticky body.
Another excellent sour beer, following the Weyerbacher Reserva, awesome brewed with cherries, delicious.

375mL thanks to womencantsail. Murky golden pour. Weak foam. Sweet melon nose, cantaloupe, sugar. Taste is light, tangy, refreshing with lemon and mango tea. Mild acid. Not really FSA or sour red as in description. Much brighter and tropical. Added as Sour/Wild because of that. Needs way more cherries added to get that inky red color and really let the kriek flavor come out. For now, only the base blond sour comes through, but it is still nice.
